article.body: Donald Trumpâs doctor on Thursday said that the president is likely to return public engagements on Saturday after completing treatment for COVID-19. âToday the President has completed his course of therapy for COVID-19 as prescribed by his team of physicians,â Dr. Sean Conley said in a public memo. âSince returning home, his physical exam has remained stable and devoid of any indications to suggest progression of illness,â Conley wrote. âOverall heâs responded extremely well to treatment, without evidence on examination of adverse therapeutic effects. Saturday will be day 10 since Thursdayâs diagnosis, and based on the trajectory of advanced diagnostics the team has been conducting, I fully anticipate the Presidentâs safe return to public engagements at that time.â Trump, 74, received experimental âpolyclonal antibodiesâ and oxygen at the White House on Friday after being diagnosed with the virus Thursday. Trump was hospitalized three nights at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., after arriving by helicopter Friday. Trump was discharged Monday. At the hospital, he received doses of the antiviral drug remdesivir and the steroid dexamethasone. In a Thursday interview with Fox Business Network, Trump attributed his apparently rapid recovery with him being âa perfect physical specimenâ and âextremely young.â House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) questioned Trumpâs sanity and unveiled a bill to set up a commission to analyze the presidentâs mental fitness, to potentially justify his removal from power under the 25th Amendment. Trump is anxious to return to the campaign trail in the remaining weeks before the Nov. 3 election. On Thursday morning, the Commission on Presidential Debates said that it would make next Thursdayâs scheduled debate in Miami between Trump and Democratic candidate Joe Biden a virtual forum â which Trump rejected. Biden in turn rejected Trumpâs proposal to delay the remaining two debates. In taped remarks, Trump credited the polyclonal antibodies infusion with making him feel better almost immediately. He reported no symptoms on Tuesday or Wednesday, Conley said in prior releases. A version of this report appears on NYPost.com.
